properties.Name: Corn Riot
properties.Agents: riot in Bedford on 21 July, related to wheat supplies
properties.Results: Committee announced they held enough corn to last until harvest, and would sell it to the poor at a reduced price. All subscribers to the fund were urged to pay their subscription immediately. Anyone rioting or committing violence would be refused relief and dealt with severely under the law.
properties.Label: Bedford, Bedfordshire

properties.Name: Food Riots
properties.Agents: Food Riots occurring at Brighthelmstone [Brighton]
properties.Results: dealt with harshly, 'awful and impressive examples' were made.
properties.Label: Birghthelmstone, Brighton, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: allegations made against Thomas Hadley including his apparent defamation of the character of Samuel Galton, his son Samuel Galton jnr and William Bird, and his apparent incitement of workmen in Birmingham to riot to prevent the firm of Farmer & Galton from completing orders placed with them, and to damage the house of Samuel Galton
properties.Label: Birmingham, England
properties.Archival sources: Birmingham: Archives, Heritage and Photography Service MS3101/D/3/1

properties.Name: Snow Hill Riot
properties.Agents: dearness of corn and every kind of provision had led some people to assemble and damage the corn mill in the town; mob attacked the corn mill of [James Pickard] at Snow Hill, Birmingham, accusing him of raising the price of flour and insulting the poor
properties.Results: magistrates not able to quell riot and sent to Lieutenant Colonel [John Callow] for his remaining troops; 2 people shot and several arrested; mill windows had been broken and Pickard's books destroyed; Riot Act read twice and most of the mob dispersed, but many reassembling in the evening; skirmish between rioters and Dragoons; "inflammatory and seditious handbills" distributed after the riot; reward of Â£100 to discover the authors
properties.Label: Birmingham, England

properties.Name: Food Riots
properties.Agents: opposition to supply shortages and rising prices
properties.Label: Black Country, England

properties.Name: Bankers' Riot
properties.Agents: a riot in Boston, presumably caused by a group of "bankers", employed in cleaning drains and embanking [canals]
properties.Results: riot was stopped but fear spread that it would break out again; local demand for 40 to 50 soldiers to keep the peace
properties.Label: Boston, Lincolnshire

properties.Name: Boston Bread Riots
properties.Agents: series of three riots by the poor
properties.Label: Boston, Province of Massachusetts Bay

properties.Name: Stamp Tax Riot
properties.Agents: taxation protest
properties.Label: Boston, Province of Massachusetts Bay

properties.Name: Turnpike Riot
properties.Agents: riot in Bristol against turnpikes
properties.Results: quelled by a troop of Bristol sailors, the eyre was forced to travel under heavy guard as the rioters intended to waylay it as they supposed it had come to hang them
properties.Label: Bristol, England
properties.Archival sources: Kent History and Library Centre U840/C1/1-32

properties.Name: Turnpike Riot
properties.Agents: [turnpike] riot in Bristol, descruction of toll bars
properties.Results: William Fudge killed, Attorney-General asked to issue a nolle prosequi for all involved in suppressing the riot, including local marchant John Brickdale.
properties.Label: Bristol, England

properties.Name: Bristol Bridge Riot / Massacre
properties.Agents: taxation riot against bridge toll from 30 September to October 2
properties.Results: violently quelled, 11 people killed, 45 injured, worst massacre of 18th-century England, magistrates endeavoured to trace the instigators of the disturbances, which they believed to be about more than the bridge-toll
properties.Label: Bristol, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: 6 June 1795, riot 'on account of the high price of provisions at this time.'
properties.Results: several accused workers gave each other alibis
properties.Label: Bristol, England

properties.Name: Food Riots
properties.Agents: uprising of the poor
properties.Label: British Isles

properties.Name: Riots in Dudley and Bromsgrove
properties.Agents: local disturbances caused by rising prices
properties.Results: disturbances in Dudley and Bromsgrove [Worcestershire] which had divided the available troops but that they had been sufficient to halt the spread of the Birmingham riot, at which the Yeomanry had arrived very early
properties.Label: Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, England

properties.Name: Carnavon / Carnarfon riot
properties.Agents: Feb. 1729: mob plundered a ship that was loading with corn; Mr. Rowland Wynne, a Justice of the Peace of Carnarvon, supposedly avetted and encouraged the rioters; rioters threatended the life of Thomas Owen, a gentleman living in the neighbourhood, who was concerned in the cargo; similar riots had occured in May 1728 when the crowd attempted to plunder another ship and to pull down Mr. Owen's house.
properties.Results: Inquiries into Rowland Wynne's behaviour followed.
properties.Label: Caernarfon, Wales

properties.Name: Food Riot
properties.Agents: rioters forced the sale of meat at Cambridge
properties.Results: Cambridgeshire had raised a troop of 80 Fencibles at great expense but they had been sent elsewhere, giving the county a strong claim for military protection until troops of Yeomanry Cavalry could be raised.
properties.Label: Cambridge, England

properties.Name: Mutiny / Strike in Chatham
properties.Agents: Riot Act was read to a number of Ropemakers who had assembled at the Dock gate in order to prevent others from entering.
properties.Results: Riot Act read to ropemakers assembled at the Dock gate; Ropeyard Officers unable to find the names of the leaders of the riot but started investigation workers who had been absent.
properties.Label: Chatham, England
properties.Archival sources: UK National Archives, ADM 106/1004/64; National Maritime Museum: The Caird Library, Manuscripts Section ADM 354/129/48

properties.Name: Mutiny / Shipwrights' Riot
properties.Agents: workmen refuse to come to duty unless they did not have to lower their chips; Justice Best read the Riot Act and they dispersed about 1 hour later; but protest continued; "damages done on the John and Joyce Tender by the Mutineers in the riot"; discussions whether a stop should be put on the working of Extra
properties.Results: considerations if the four named persons should be dismissed from the Service; Mrs. Beverstock asks for replacement of her involved servant sent to sea.
properties.Label: Chatham, England
properties.Archival sources: National Maritime Museum: The Caird Library, Manuscripts Section ADM 354/153/49 and following

properties.Name: Food Riot
properties.Agents: riotous mob had forced the sale of meat at 4d per pound
properties.Label: Chatteris, Isle of Ely

properties.Name: Formation of (Protestant) Peep O'Day Boys and (Catholic) Defenders
properties.Agents: sectarian conflict between agrarian Protestant association and local Catholics
properties.Label: Co. Armagh, Ireland

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: industrial unrest at Coal-pit Heath on 7-8 July 1783 when miners threatened the life of John Walker, the colliery bailif
properties.Results: reading of the Riot Act was only narrowly avoided
properties.Label: Coal-pit Heath, Nottingham, England
properties.Archival sources: Nottingham University Library, Department of Manuscripts and Special Collections Mi E 16/51

properties.Name: Food Riot
properties.Agents: Food Riot among iron and coal workers, 400 to 500 men with bludgeons had had to be dispersed
properties.Results: riot was only suppressed by the masters of the works and by the yeomanry cavalry
properties.Label: Colebrooke Dale / Coalbrookdale, Wales

properties.Name: Colchester Riot
properties.Agents: riot by weavers for higher wages
properties.Label: Colchester, England

properties.Name: Irish Volunteers' Parade
properties.Agents: demanding removal of restrictions on Irish trade
properties.Label: College Green, Dublin, Ireland

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: Mandate from Sir William Coryton to constables of North Hill for certain men and a woman of that parish to appear before him at Newton for causing a riot and stealing corn etc.
properties.Label: Cornwall, Britain

properties.Name: Miners' Riot
properties.Agents: rioting miners in Cornwall (Helston, Truro and Redruth) on 6 April 1796: The miners there are said to be 'strongly tinged with Jacobinical Principles'.
properties.Results: The Worcestershire Militia were sent for support; riot quelled under the command of Major St John and his reinforcements. Several arrest were made an hour after the riot act was read.
properties.Label: Cornwall, Britain
properties.Archival sources: UK National Archives, HO 42/38/82, Cornwall Record Office QS/1/6/361-379

properties.Name: Steelboy / Hearts of Steel disturbances
properties.Agents: exclusively Protestant movement to address grievances about the sharp rise of rent and evictions
properties.Label: County Antrim, Ulster, Ireland

properties.Name: Old Price Riots
properties.Agents: local protest against rising price of threatre tickets
properties.Label: Covent Garden, London, England

properties.Name: Weavers' Riot
properties.Agents: two day riot at Culmstock by weavers from Cullompton and Bradninch
properties.Results: recommending that a company of dragoons be stationed at those two places to prevent the outbreak of similar trouble
properties.Label: Culmstock, England

properties.Name: Corn Riot
properties.Agents: Case of William Fisher who was sentenced to transportation for taking corn during a riot in Dewsbury and is now recommended for mercy.
properties.Results: Petition from inhabitants of Wakefield and others in support of the recommendations.
properties.Label: Dewsbury, England

properties.Name: Turnpike Riot
properties.Agents: riot at Dirham, Gloucestershire, over a turnpike
properties.Results: request for more troops made
properties.Label: Dirham, Gloucestershire

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: 'Dangerous Riot' at Diss
properties.Label: Diss, England

properties.Name: Food Riots / Irish Famine
properties.Agents: hungry townspeople "vented their frustration on grain dealers, meal-mongers and bakers, and when they turned to direct action the most likely flashpoints were markets or warehouses"
properties.Results: permanent change in the country's demographic and economic landscape
properties.Label: Ireland (e.g. Drogheda and other parts of the Empire

properties.Name: Riots in Dudley and Bromsgrove
properties.Agents: local disturbances caused by rising prices
properties.Results: disturbances in Dudley and Bromsgrove [Worcestershire] which had divided the available troops but that they had been sufficient to halt the spread of the Birmingham riot, at which the Yeomanry had arrived very early
properties.Label: Dudley, Britain

properties.Name: Beer exportation riot
properties.Agents: local population opposing the exportation of beer
properties.Label: Dysart, Fifeshire, Scotland

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: insurrection of a mob [riot] at Dysart in Fifeshire and other places, upon the exporting of beer.
properties.Label: Dysart, Fifeshire, Scotland

properties.Name: Spitalfields Riots
properties.Agents: labour protest of weavers, following a downturn in the silk weaving industry
properties.Label: East End of London

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: violence, the removal of the chest containing the Corporation records, the unlawful securing of the Town Hall, and the unsuccessful attempt to read the Riot Act
properties.Label: East Sussex, England

properties.Name: Food Riots / Bread Riots
properties.Agents: regional protest against price rises
properties.Label: England and Scotland

properties.Name: Food Riot
properties.Agents: uprising of the poor
properties.Label: Falmouth, England

properties.Name: Malt Tax Riot
properties.Agents: local riot in June, (later blamed on Jacobites and tolerated by several magistrates), mob refuse payment of the Malt Tax until those involved have been punished, destruction of Daniel Campbell's house; attack on the troops, who opened fire and then retreated to Dunbarton Castle;
properties.Results: Gen Wade asked to quell riot violently, several people incl. Jean Mackie killed, goods carried away from Daniel Campbell's house, leaders sentenced, "horried and barbarous" actions by Capt. Bushell, pardon granted to Bushell and others who had intervened
properties.Label: Glasgow, Scotland
properties.Archival sources: UK National Archives, SP 54/15/28, UK National Archives, SP 54/17/10A-13, UK National Archives, SP 54/15/97-98

properties.Name: Suspected Riot
properties.Agents: [Lord Lieutenant of Gloucestershire]: concern that the people will riot unless the circulation of cash, for the principal clothiers in the neighbourhood to pay their workmen, happens within a week, the country bankers issuing none at present. Berkeley states that there are no troops locally as they have all been ordered to march with General [James Rooke] to Milford [Pembrokeshire].
properties.Label: Gloucestershire, England

properties.Name: Food Riots in Britain
properties.Agents: uprising of the poor
properties.Label: British Isles

properties.Name: Food Riots
properties.Agents: uprising of the poor
properties.Label: British Isles

properties.Name: Gunnis Lake Mine protest
properties.Agents: Sampson of Gunnis Lake Mine [Gunnislake] with great difficulty restrained 80 men who had assembled that morning intent on persuading the Callington magistrates to reduce the abnormally high price of wheat and barley in the locality. They had stated that their children were crying out for bread and if nothing was done they would plunder the farmers
properties.Results: resolved without violence
properties.Label: Gunnis Lake Mine, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: worries that the tinners [tin miners] would riot unless price of corn was lowered
properties.Label: Harewood, Cornwall

properties.Name: Scotch drover riot
properties.Agents: riot at Hempton by Scotch drovers
properties.Label: Hempton, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: riot at Hinckley of the inhabitants on the dearness of provisions, assembly of circa 22 people before the Bull, Mr Brown declared the bread was not weight and offered that person a guinea that would bring him a loaf that was deficient to make the baker pay the penalty, Justice Abney & Greavs were assisting the military & went into the mob declaring they'd read the riot act & then they might take the consequences, but they did not.
properties.Results: One fellow is brought to jail taken from the Huxter's shop at the corner opposite Mrs Brown's. The cavalry made a feint of going off when they dispered the mob the first time, & pretended to go to Nuneaton where there was rioting on the Saturday, & very bad doings indeed at Coventry market the day before. When the Cavelry got as afar as the Harrow the rebels assembled again & the trumpet sounded & they came clattering back with sword in hand & rode them down at once.William Lovett said he found as great an inclination at Sapcote for the same business both Monday night & Tuesday. Tom Gent found it necessary to declare he'd set them in the stocks if they'd not disperse.
properties.Label: Hinckley, England

properties.Name: Food Riots
properties.Agents: Food Riots occurring at Horsham, in Sussex
properties.Results: dealt with harshly, 'awful and impressive examples' were made.
properties.Label: Horsham, Sussex

properties.Name: Machine breaking in Huddersfield
properties.Results: several machine breakers executed for riot
properties.Label: Huddersfield, England
properties.Archival sources: West Yorkshire Archive Service, Kirklees KC703

properties.Name: Banker (canal construction worker) riot
properties.Agents: riot by numerous bankers [canal construction workers]: Following a riot on market day instigated by bankers demanding affordable food, 5 people had been arrested by special constables and imprisoned in the House of Correction. The bankers had threatened to muster 1,000 comrades to set the prisoners free, whereupon Oswin had requested the provision of a guard from the Commanding Officer and the crowd had dispersed.
properties.Results: Francis Smeath, John Edwards, Thomas May, Edward Hicks and Elias Huddlestone, known as bankers, arrested on 1 August for assembling, behaving in a riotous and tumultuous manner, and for refusing to disperse / offenders having solemnly promised not to be guilty of such offences again, were discharged "with a warning to all not to offend against the public peace"
properties.Label: Isle of Ely

properties.Name: Colliers' toll complaint
properties.Agents: The colliers' letter to the turnpike': an open letter from the colliers of Kingswood Forest, in defence of a threatened legal action for riot and rebellion, complaining about tolls, and laying the blame for the poor condition of the roads in Kingswood on the actions of the lord of the manor.
properties.Label: Kingswood, England

properties.Name: Corn price riot
properties.Agents: John Shaw and Edward Horsley, convicted of inciting to riot and to forcing the farmers to sell corn at their own prices / James Nicholson and Matthew Thompson, convicted of committing disorderly acts and publicly proclaiming the price of corn
properties.Results: arrest of several rioters / apprehension of the cryer of Knottingley and investigation who paid him to cry the riot
properties.Label: Knottingley, England

properties.Name: Corn Riot
properties.Agents: riot at Knottingley, corn in transit had been stopped and detained, greatest discontent in the populous areas to the west
properties.Label: Knottingley, England

properties.Name: Corn Price Riot
properties.Agents: riot triggered by rising, unaffordable corn prices
properties.Results: âKingâs troopsâ ended the riot, killing eight or nine people.
properties.Label: Leeds, England

properties.Name: Turnpike riot
properties.Agents: conflict with rioters against the turnpikes in Leeds, destruction of Beeston turnpike bar, including the presence of ninety soldiers to quell the riot
properties.Results: arrest of three rioters, beseiging of and attack on the place where the prisoners were under examination, 10 rioters killed, 27 injured.
properties.Label: Leeds, England

properties.Name: Limerick Riot
properties.Agents: riot near Limerick (Oct.1778) against taxation
properties.Label: Limerick, Ireland

properties.Name: Bankers' riot
properties.Agents: outrageous lawless bankers' building canals at Tydd St Mary [Lincolnshire] and from the Old River [Nene] to Outwell. Those at Tydd St Mary had threatened farmers in the parish of Tydd St Giles, requiring them to supply them with bread and to sell them mutton at 4d per pound, failing which their houses would be razed to the ground.
properties.Results: The farmers had come to Wisbech to consult the town gentlemen about the supply of bread to the poor but had been disappointed by deferment of the discussion and now, in great fear of their wheat being seized as it was reaped, requested immediate military protection.
properties.Label: Lincolnshire, England

properties.Name: Ely and Littleport riots
properties.Agents: reaction to unemployment and price rises
properties.Label: Littleport, Cambridgeshire, England

properties.Name: Seamenâs revolt
properties.Agents: public protest, sabotage and prison escapes in Liverpool led by seamen
properties.Label: Liverpool, England

properties.Name: Calico Riots
properties.Agents: different parts of London; weavers protest against cotton imports from India, involving attacks on women wearing calico [by weavers], and constables attacked by 'a great mob', in Bunhill [London], as they escorted rioters to gaol; ca. 2000 men tried to pull down the prison in Spitalfields;
properties.Results: Examinations followed against several weavers and haberdashers for direct participation or "praising the weavers" [for their recent riot], and saying the price of wool had fallen by 50 per cent because of the competition from calico.
properties.Label: London, England
properties.Archival sources: UK National Archives, SP 35/16/114, UK National Archives, SP 35/21/87

properties.Name: Weavers' riot
properties.Agents: fresh concern that the riot not only continued but also that the weavers seemed to be more and more exasperated
properties.Label: London, England

properties.Name: (Rumoured) Gin Act Riots
properties.Agents: protest against an act designed to reduce the consumption of gin, rising tensions across London as anti-prohibition ballads, satirical plays and articles mocking the luxury of the upper classes spread
properties.Label: London, England

properties.Name: London Gin Riots
properties.Agents: taxation riot
properties.Label: London, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: Riot at the Exchange
properties.Label: London, England

properties.Name: Woolcombers' riot
properties.Agents: violent reaction of the woolcombers to the failure in the House of Commons on 9 May of the bill to abolish woolcombing machines; fears that Mr Pitt would be attacked for opposing the bill; Mendip miners in Somerset already offered to destroy the machine at Twerton near Bath.
properties.Label: London, England

properties.Name: Battle of the Diamond / Foundation of the Orange Society
properties.Agents: planned confrontation between the Catholic Defenders and the Protestant Peep o' Day Boys
properties.Results: The Peep o' Day Boys were the victors, killing circa 6 Defenders, with some wounded Peep o' Day boys in return.
properties.Label: Loughgall, Co. Armagh, Ireland

properties.Name: Wage Riots
properties.Agents: riot at Mansfield 26 October 1723 caused by the reading of the statute for assessing and appointing rates and wages for artificers, labourers and servants
properties.Label: Mansfield, England
properties.Archival sources: Nottingham University Library, Department of Manuscripts and Special Collections Mol 249

properties.Name: Whiskey Rebellion / Whiskey Insurrection
properties.Agents: Protests over taxes in Pittsburgh and the Monongahela Valley
properties.Results: President George Washington invokes martial law and crushes insurrection with 13,000 men.
properties.Label: Monongahela Valley, USA

properties.Name: Beginning of the Whiteboy Movement
properties.Agents: secret agrarian organisation violently defends tenant farmer land rights
properties.Label: Munster, Ireland

properties.Name: Whiteboy / Rightboy Disturbances
properties.Agents: agrarian conflict
properties.Label: Munster, Ireland

properties.Name: Expected Food Riots
properties.Agents: Mayor of Salisbury, complaining of the practice whereby dealers buy up everything in the market before the inhabitants are served so that the latter must pay extortionate prices to the former; and requiring the mayor and corporation to 'execute their office' and gain the goodwill of the city or, failing this, to expect riot and the destruction of the carriers.
properties.Label: New Sarum, Salisbury, Wiltshire

properties.Name: Corn Riot
properties.Agents: local riot at Newhaven, Sussex; taking of a vessel property of Messrs Catt and Barton, millers of Bishopstone Tide Mill, Newhaven, Sussex; and the removal of 157 sacks of flour from the vessel
properties.Results: William Midwinter, a soldier of the Oxfordshire Militia, convicted (along with William Avery another soldier in the same regiment); accused petition for clemency
properties.Label: Newhaven, Sussex, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: Mary Sillsby, accused of stealing wheat during a riot, asking that she may have a free pardon.
properties.Results: petitions on behalf of Mary Sillsby for free pardon
properties.Label: Northampton, England

properties.Name: Enclosure Riot
properties.Agents: riot in Northants following enclosures by Lord Powis
properties.Results: J Freeman to Secretary Boyle, from Wellingborough, Northants: His proceedings in dispersing a threatened riot against Lord Powis' enclosure.
properties.Label: Northants, England

properties.Name: Workhouse Riots
properties.Agents: rioting of the poor (against newly established work houses) in several northern towns
properties.Results: demolition of a workhouse
properties.Label: Northern England

properties.Name: Protest by journeyman woolcombers
properties.Agents: Norwich or Yarmouth between 1751 and 1752
properties.Label: Norwich or Yarmouth, England
properties.Archival sources: Norfolk Record Office MC 79/1, fo. 6 522 x 5

properties.Name: Colliers' Riot
properties.Agents: riot by a great number of colliers, County Justice fled for fear of the colliers, scarcely a constable that dares to execute a warrant and 'it is only the troops that keep the colliers in awe'; reports that the Nottingham colliers threaten a rescue (of their arrested associates) and have sent to Coleorton, Leicestershire for the assistance of the colliers there.
properties.Results: arrest of three of the rioters namely Thomas Johnson and William Johnson of Cossall and William Waplington of Trowel; apprehension of some of the riot's ringleaders namely Thomas Palmer, Thomas James and Samuel Waterhouse alias Baker; a windmill belonging to one Mr Foulds and a water corn mill were damaged
properties.Label: Nottingham, England

properties.Name: Nottingham Cheese Riot
properties.Agents: local citizens vs. Merchants
properties.Label: Nottingham, Northern England

properties.Name: Bread riots
properties.Agents: Riot incited by high bread prices; a group of colliers was going to Nuneaton with mischievous intentions; mob dragged Thomas Ball, an elderly baker, out of his house, forced him to sign a deed to sell flour at a reduced price, and threatened to hang him if he refused; rioters collected signatures (against high bread prices) in town and sold flour from a local mill; rioters consisted mainly of women and children, as most of the colliers from Bedworth had gone to Coventry. On Tuesday night the mob, which had been rioting all day in Coventry, sent small groups all over the county including to Nuneaton.
properties.Results: [John Newdigate Ludford] of Ansley Hall, Captain Commandant of the Nuneaton Yeomanry and an acting magistrate in the Hemlingford Hundred of Warwickshire, intervened with his troops. On Wednesday morning Ludford was joined on Camp Hill by Captain Dugdale Geast of the Atherstone Troop and Captain [Abraham Bracebridge] of the Atherstone Company of Volunteers. After patrolling Nuneaton and Atherstone, Ludford stood down his troop and the neighbourhood had been quiet ever since, although there had been trouble in Hinckley, Coventry and Birmingham.
properties.Label: Nuneaton, England

properties.Name: Fries's Rebellion
properties.Agents: tax revolt among Pennsylvania Dutch farmers led by John Fries
properties.Label: Pennsylvania, North America

properties.Name: Tinners' riot
properties.Agents: riot by tinners [i.e. tin miners]
properties.Results: magistrates entreating that no more troops be sent; Mayor and Deputy Recorder of Penryn requested that the names of some rioters by published in the London Gazette
properties.Label: Penryn, Cornwall
properties.Archival sources: UK National Archives, SP 36/108/1/98, UK National Archives, SP 36/108/2/24

properties.Name: Tinners' Riot
properties.Agents: tinners riot at Penryn
properties.Label: Penryn, Cornwall

properties.Name: Market riot
properties.Agents: riot at Plymouth market which the magistrates and extra constables had subdued; great concern over the shortage of provisions, especially corn, normal sources of supply in Hampshire and Sussex are almost exhausted.
properties.Label: Plymoth, Devon, England

properties.Name: Ropemakers' Riot
properties.Agents: riot involving ropemakers (many of whom later begged for pardon and promised better conduct)
properties.Results: several ropemakers petitioned in 1747 because they were refused servants or apprentices because of their involvement in the riot.
properties.Label: Plymouth, England
properties.Archival sources: UK National Archives, ADM 106/1037/120, UK National Archives, ADM 106/1043/53, UK National Archives, ADM 106/1039/204

properties.Name: Apprentices' Riot in Plymouth
properties.Agents: day appointed for the commemoration of the 5th [November] being Powder Plot and an allowed holiday, is on Sunday and the workmen are entitled to claim a day's pay for half a day's work. The Artificers thought that by the alteration of style they had half a day due to them, yesterday and were mutinous on the ringing of the bell. Observe that their meeting was concerted by the majority of the workmen and the apprentices urged on by them to effect it, who were the only acting ones of this occasion. List of 11 apprentices and their Masters, who were prominent in the riot. Moone and Webb were particularly audacious and ask for directions.
properties.Results: William Evans, shipwright and former apprentice, the mistress of an involved servant, and Richard Hawkins, Chaulker at Plymouth, petition.
properties.Label: Plymouth, England

properties.Name: Shipwrights' Riot
properties.Agents: Deposition against the rioters sworn before William Rickman, Mayor and Samuel Brady. When called to the riot at the gates he was abused and dirt and stones were thrown at him. Account of persons concerned in the late riot. Alexander Pooling and Edward Atwick are said to be ringleaders and nine others Enclosed in 68.
properties.Results: Several workers petition to be re-admitted after the riot and claimed they were not involved.
properties.Label: Portsmouth, England

properties.Name: Riots (in the West Country)
properties.Agents: Sir Geo. Savile at Preston to John Hewett at Shireoaks; militia activities suppressing riots: 'came yesterday (to Preston) in the course of military duty, our General (Faucitt) being here. (...) A great deal of night work; and our enemy is a kind of invisible Potentate with whom we can neither fight nor treat. They assemble on the hills (as the West Country lads hunt) by shouting or drums, go to destroy Mills used in the Cotton manufacture etc. and disperse as easily as they met and as ready to meet again, observing always to go where there is no military.
properties.Results: Only one Battle having happened when 6 Dragoons drove 2 or 3 hundred back and some into the River where one of the Dragoons, alighting and jumping in after and swearing he would cut the man's head off brought him out like a drowned Rat. What could the poor man do, if he ducked he was drowned, if he popp'ed up his head it was cut off? So the victory was compleat. I am, from a poor private Colonel of one Regiment, become a General of 5 Armies for into so many parts are my troops divided'.
properties.Label: Preston, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: riot on 15 Jan., off the shore near Pwllheli, allegedly led by Henry Hugh Price of Deneio, at which corn - being loaded under a contract with Evan Ellis of Llannor to carry barley, rye and potatoes from Pwllheli to Barmouth in Merioneth - was stolen from his boat, the Blackbird sloop, and from the horses on the shore from where it was being loaded
properties.Results: riot act read on three occassions, several rioters identified
properties.Label: Pwllheli, Wales
properties.Archival sources: Gwynedd Archives, Caernarfon Record Office XQS/1752/50

properties.Name: Riot of turnpike cutters
properties.Agents: a riot of turnpike cutters at Ross Fair
properties.Label: Ross Fair, Hereford, England

properties.Name: Corn Riot
properties.Agents: public meeting held at Saxlingham [Nethergate] at which a man wearing a hat with a ribband or cockade made a speech and gave away leaflets, a copy of which was enclosed. Several similar meetings had been held, as the high price of corn and other necessities was providing an excuse for ill-disposed persons to harangue the common people. Fellowes had issued a warrant for the arrest of the speaker James Besey. A postscript states that he had been told of a dangerous riot at Diss.
properties.Results: pamphlet signed by 'A friend to reform', was circulated, which - inter alia - criticised the House of Commons' commitment to the present system, composed as it was of 'land-monopolists, commissaries, contractors and pensioners', and describes 'Our Hell-Born Minister' as no better than the Empress of Russia, the King of Prussia or the Emperor of Germany
properties.Label: Saxlingham, Nethergate

properties.Name: Food Riots / Bread Riots
properties.Agents: regional protest against price rises
properties.Label: England and Scotland

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: riot at the muster of the workmen by the Clerk of the Clerk of the Cheque because eight of the artificers and labourers were mulcted for quitting their work and purchasing mackerel at the Pier Head.
properties.Results: Request that the Commissioner should enquire into it.
properties.Label: Sheerness, England

properties.Name: Sheffield Riot
properties.Agents: violence against the debtors' goal and the residence of Vicar Wilkinson
properties.Label: Sheffield, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: riot near Bath on Thursday [14 December] between 200 and 300 men with faces blackened, armed with bludgeons, who entered the house of a sheargrinder at Nunney near Froome [Frome] and demolished shears; rioters numbering 800 or 900 then proceeded to Twerton with a view to hanging Bamford and 2 of his men and burning down Bamford's works and those of Culliford and Company across the river.
properties.Results: cavalry faced the rioters; twelve men taken into custody and the other rioters disbanded; prisoners examined but no sufficient proof
properties.Label: Somerset, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: alleged bread or Corn Riot at Somerton
properties.Label: Somerton, England
properties.Archival sources: Somerset Heritage Centre (South West Heritage Trust) DD/S/BT/27/10/2

properties.Name: Occupation of the mint
properties.Agents: about 200 unarmed men occupied the Mint in Southwark High Street, [Surrey]
properties.Label: Southwark, England

properties.Name: Anticipated tinners' riot
properties.Agents: mayor, burgesses and principal inhabitants request that forces be kept in district, as tinners are threatening to riot
properties.Label: St. Ives, Cornwall

properties.Name: Tinners' riot
properties.Agents: riot by tinners from Redruth and other parishes in St. Ives to try to seize stocks of corn;
properties.Results: local apologise to neighbouring parishes for the troubles and assure that market-goers will not be assaulted, Government reward for the apprehension of ringleaders
properties.Label: St. Ives, Cornwall

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: riot and the damage to a shop and windows, property of Bradford Norbury, corn dealer at Stockport Marker Place, on 1 August 1795; Reverend Charles Prescot was the magistrate who read the Riot Act on the day of the riot.
properties.Results: petitions on behalf of William Cadman and John Williams, convicted (with Thomas Taylor and Samuel Orr; Taylor received 12 months imprisonment; Orr received 6 months imprisonment), at the Chester Assizes, in August 1795; grounds for clemency: both have families to support who are currently in distress, already served 16 months in prison and good behaviour during confinement. Recommendation: remission of sentence on condition that the securities are given as stated in initial sentence.
properties.Label: Stockport, England

properties.Name: Corn Riot
properties.Agents: riot against the export of corn in Stockton, riot lasted 3 days and local magistrates feared physical injury and further outrages.
properties.Results: John Hedworth and G[eorge] Vane, J.P's at Stockton, to [Newcastle] that they are attempting to suppress a riot and requesting a company of Foot from York until peace is restored.
properties.Label: Stockton, England

properties.Name: Flour Riot
properties.Agents: Tewkesbury [Gloucestershire] in late June 1795: rioting when wheat flour had been forcibly taken from barges at the quay (property of James Lamb) and carried off, mainly by females; aim was to prevent flour from being sold elsewhere.
properties.Results: civil power suppressed the riot with difficulty; arrests made; collective petition on behalf of several men and women who had been convicted; sex and young age of the arrested were taken into consideration.
properties.Label: Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire
properties.Archival sources: UK National Archives, HO 42/35/20, UK National Archives, HO 47/18/38

properties.Name: Oakboy / Hearts of Oak
properties.Agents: agrarian disturbances by rural population
properties.Label: Ulster, Ireland

properties.Name: Tinners' Riot
properties.Agents: riot, mostly by tinners, at Wadebridge on 15 January had occurred without serious consequences; that moves had since been made to call out a large number of men from the Polgooth tin mine to prevent corn being exported from Wadebridge and Padstow; and that the messenger had been arrested and committed to Launceston gaol but, in the face of a mob marching on Lostwithiel, had been released on bail. Gregor adds a postscript lending credence to the view that corn was being smuggled to France, especially from Looe, and that Government should attend to this in order to pacify the tinners.
properties.Results: orders had been given by the War Office for a detachment of the 25th Regiment to be sent from Plymouth to Bodmin and for a detachment of the South Devon Militia to move to Launceston
properties.Label: Wadebridge, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: memorial of Nathaniel Bell asking recompense for settling a `rebellion' by merchant seamen, and averting a riot by coal heavers at Wapping
properties.Label: Wapping, Middlesex, England

properties.Name: Coal heavers' riot
properties.Agents: coal heavers' riot,
properties.Results: rioter arrested for allegedly shooting a police officer, who, according to witnesses, was rather accidentally shot by one of his colleagues from an office window; debate whether rioters had any firearms at all
properties.Label: Wapping, Middlesex, England

properties.Name: Wellington Factory Riot
properties.Agents: Wellington factory riot, 1759
properties.Label: Wellington, England
properties.Archival sources: Somerset Heritage Centre (South West Heritage Trust) DD\TB/18/7

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: riot in Wells [Wells-next-the-sea], a seaport, over the shipping of flour. A large number of women, supported by others, had by their riotous behaviour prevented the shipping of flour destined for London. As [Thomas Coke] the magistrate was not available, Townsend and the Reverend Hoste felt it their duty to go to Wells: they also ordered a company of the Pembrokeshire Militia to go from their base in Holt [Norfolk] to Warham to wait for further orders. Hoste warned the women of the illegality of their actions and the possible consequences: he also reminded them that they had previously been supplied with flour shipped in from Yarmouth, and, that once peace was restored the magistrates were willing to attend to their needs.
properties.Results: Having twice read the proclamation in the turmoil, Townshend ordered the militia to march in: they drove the mob off with bayonets and thus secured the safety of the ship and the flour. Coke then arrived and arranged a date to hear from the women about their situation, after which the flour was loaded on the ship and the militia were quartered in the town. Townshend thinks that by this action they have prevented similar disturbances occurring in other parts of Norfolk.
properties.Label: Wells-next-the-sea, England

properties.Name: Anticipated Sailors' Riot
properties.Agents: situation in Wells [Norfolk] after flour had been shipped: threatened riot by the sailors. It is thought that during the last riot the sailors would have fired on the magistrates and troops if the opportunity had arisen.
properties.Label: Wells, Norfolk, England

properties.Name: Corn Riot
properties.Agents: account of expenses of a sufferer from Corn Riot
properties.Label: West Yorkshire, England
properties.Archival sources: West Yorkshire Archive Service, Wakefield QS1/123/2

properties.Name: Shays' Rebellion
properties.Agents: privately-funded local militia in Massachusetts against court proceedings collecting taxes and debts
properties.Label: Western Massachusetts

properties.Name: Whiskey Rebellion / Whiskey Insurrection
properties.Agents: Protests over taxes in Pittsburgh and the Monongahela Valley
properties.Results: President George Washington invokes martial law and crushes insurrection with 13,000 men.
properties.Label: Western Pennsylvania, USA

properties.Name: Industrial Riot
properties.Agents: reporting that a meeting of journeymen carpenters had resolved to pull down certain houses if the slave trade were abolished, recommending the reinforcement of the 30th Regiment of Foot by 3 troops of Horse, to be quartered at Wigan, Warrington and Ormskirk respectively
properties.Results: military assistance was sent and material damage was averted
properties.Label: Wigan, England

properties.Name: Colliers' Riot
properties.Agents: colliers from Nook Colliery had decided to board a sloop at Haverfordwest, loaded with butter for Bristol, and to divide the cargo amongst themselves. Philipps had asked Captain [Stephen Longcroft], Regulating Captain at the port of Milford, to provide an escort for the vessel. Philipps then met a great crowd of men, women and children, armed with wooden clubs, in the main street of Haverfordwest and had advised them to disperse. Mr Bateman, an attorney, and James Summers, his curate, had come to Philipps's aid and beaten off the attackers. Mr Milles of Lincoln's Inn and others came to assist, the Militia were summoned and ordered to load their firearms, and the Riot Act was read, at which the colliers ran off, two being arrested and jailed.
properties.Results: Without this intervention in the High Street, the colliers would have reached the Quay and the sloop would have been gutted. The sloop sailed that evening with a merchant, a magistrate and 20 militia men on board. [Lieutenant Colonel Thomas Knox] had agreed to bring the Fishguard Fencibles to Haverfordwest, allowing the Militia to return to Pembroke. Philipps had released the jailed colliers after they had entered into recognizances for their good behaviour. They had informed him that, had they succeeded in unloading the butter, they intended to seize all the corn at the next market. Philipps understood that the colliers had been encouraged by one or more people of property in Haverfordwest and he suggests an advertisement be placed in the Gazette offering a reward for the discovery of the offenders, ensuring that such advertisement be copied in papers that were read locally such as the Evening Mail , the Sun , the Star and Farley's Bristol Journal.
properties.Label: Williamston, Pembrokeshire

properties.Name: Food Riot at Ely
properties.Agents: a riot at Ely a few days earlier as a result of the scarcity and high price of provisions.
properties.Results: Fearing another riot on market day, the magistrates had asked for troops to protect them. Hardwicke asks for the magistrates to be given the power to call on the cavalry stationed at Mildenhall, even though it is in Suffolk.
properties.Label: Wimpole, England

properties.Name: Wheat Riot
properties.Agents: Although constables had been charged to use every effort to keep the peace and prevent tumult and riot, the inhabitants of Witney had seized wheat being taken out of the area and brought it back for sale at a low price. The lower class of people were saying that farmers and jobbers were demanding double the price they would have taken three weeks before.
properties.Results: Willoughby concludes by saying that, if Government had wished to remove grain from the county, they should have satisfied the inhabitants that enough would be left for their own consumption.
properties.Label: Witney, England

properties.Name: Shipwrights' Riot / Strike
properties.Agents: Shipwrights in Woolwich yard did not come to work and expressed solidarity for fellow workers in Chatham; John Midford was accused of being one of the leaders.
properties.Results: assistance of the Civil Magistrates was asked to quell the riot; ringleaders were sought.
properties.Label: Woolwhich, England
properties.Archival sources: UK National Archives, ADM 106/1229/259; National Maritime Museum: The Caird Library, Manuscripts Section ADM 354/196/315

properties.Name: Workmen Riot
properties.Agents: riot (or strike) by workmen at Woolwich Yard in August; warrants against six persons concerned; three ringleaders identified;
properties.Results: Forces detached to Woolwich to quell the riot and report of their visit to the yard. Several demands for reimbursements, pardon or rehabilitation coming in between 1740 and 1742.
properties.Label: Woolwich, England

properties.Name: Workers' Riot
properties.Results: Samuel Harwood proposed for the third foreman, was absent for only one day, William Miller, proposed to be fourth, was absent but he has been made a Foreman, and James Carter proposed for the new eleven shillings a week Foreman has also been absent but is not riotous, only misled by the Deptford men.
properties.Label: Woolwich, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: The Greatest Riot in October this year as ever was known in this County when they assembled in & about Wotton to the Number of 800 or 1,000 Men, Women, & pull'd down & destroyed all the Boulting Mills in this neighbourhood plundered Farmer Collet of Alderley to the Value of Two Hundred Pounds in Cheese & pull'd down several Houses & did great damage throughout the County under pretence of lowering the price of Provisions.
properties.Results: Many of them were committed to Gloster Gaol Nine were condemned by a Special Commission, ye Judges Lds. Perret & Aston, three of whom were executed, the rest reprived for Transportation.
properties.Label: Wotton, Gloucestershire, England

properties.Name: Sheffield Food Riot
properties.Agents: social / economic grievances
properties.Label: Yorkshire, England

properties.Name: Boston Tea Party
properties.Agents: conflict over trade and taxation
properties.Label: Boston, Province of Massachusetts Bay

properties.Name: Kett's Rebellion
properties.Agents: revolt during the reign of Edward VI, largely in response to the enclosure of land
properties.Results: Victory for Edwardian forces, rebellion suppressed, execution of rebel commanders
properties.Label: Norfolk, England

properties.Name: Whiskey Rebellion / Whiskey Insurrection
properties.Agents: Protests over taxes in Pittsburgh and the Monongahela Valley
properties.Results: President George Washington invokes martial law and crushes insurrection with 13,000 men.
properties.Label: Western Pennsylvania, USA

properties.Name: Revolt of the Housewives
properties.Agents: Food Riots with prominent role of women, linked with land enclosures
properties.Label: England

properties.Name: Oxfordshire Rising of 1596
properties.Agents: intended march on London to protest against bad harvest and unprecedented poverty
properties.Label: Oxfordshire, England
